title: Jeff Ross
text:
Jeffrey Ross Lifschultz (born September 13, 1965), is an American stand-up comedian and actor. He is best known as the "Roastmaster General" for his <a href="insult%20comedy">insult comedy</a>, his multiple appearances at celebrity <a href="Roast%20%28comedy%29">roasts</a> held by the <a href="New%20York%20Friars%20Club">New York Friars Club</a>, the "<a href="Comedy%20Central%20Roast">Comedy Central Roast</a>" television series, and the Netflix historical comedy series "<a href="Historical%20Roasts">Historical Roasts</a>". In 2009 the "<a href="Chicago%20Tribune">Chicago Tribune</a>" called Ross "the new millennium <a href="Don%20Rickles">Don Rickles</a>." His directorial debut, the 2006 documentary "", won the prize for Best Film at the <a href="Comedia%20%28festival%29">Comedia film festival</a> held at the <a href="Just%20for%20Laughs">Just for Laughs</a> comedy festival in <a href="Montreal">Montreal</a>.
Early life.
Ross was raised in <a href="Newark%2C%20New%20Jersey">Newark, New Jersey</a>, until he was in second grade; then his family moved to <a href="Union%20Township%2C%20Union%20County%2C%20New%20Jersey">Union, New Jersey</a>, and later to <a href="Springfield%20Township%2C%20Union%20County%2C%20New%20Jersey">Springfield, New Jersey</a>, where he attended <a href="Jonathan%20Dayton%20High%20School">Jonathan Dayton High School</a>. He is of Jewish heritage and has a younger sister named Robyn. His mother Marsha died from <a href="leukemia">leukemia</a> when he was 14 years old. His father died of drug-related causes when Ross was 19 years old when Ross was attending college and his sister was a <a href="Senior%20%28education%29">senior</a> in high school. His father owned and ran Clinton Manor Catering, a catering business that was started by Ross's great-grandmother. The business was located in <a href="Newark%2C%20New%20Jersey">Newark, New Jersey</a>, and later moved to <a href="Union%20Township%2C%20Union%20County%2C%20New%20Jersey">Union, New Jersey.</a>
Ross attended <a href="Boston%20University">Boston University</a> as a broadcasting and film <a href="Major%20%28academic%29">major</a> with a <a href="Minor%20%28academic%29">minor</a> in <a href="political%20science">political science</a>. He graduated from the <a href="Boston%20University%20College%20of%20Communication">Boston University College of Communication</a> in 1987. Ross also worked as the music director at the university's student-run radio station <a href="WTBU%20%28Boston%20University%29">WTBU</a> in addition to working for the university's <a href="public%20radio">public radio</a> station <a href="WBUR">WBUR</a> where he worked as an <a href="audio%20engineer">audio engineer</a>.
Ross credits his tough upbringing in New Jersey for helping him develop his talent for insult comedy, which he says he developed as a defense mechanism. Ross stated in an interview with "<a href="The%20Atlanta%20Constitution">The Atlanta Constitution</a>": "Everyone in my family was good at [roasting]. I had to quickly learn not just to take a joke but to give it back. My uncle Murray was the first to bust my chops. We called him mean Murray."
Career.
Stand-up, writing and roast comedy.
Ross began performing stand-up in 1994 at <a href="open%20mic">open mic</a> nights at the <a href="Boston%20Comedy%20Club">Boston Comedy Club</a>, a now defunct comedy venue in New York City. By 1995 he was also performing at such comedy clubs as the <a href="Comedy%20Cellar">Comedy Cellar</a> and <a href="Stand%20Up%20NY">Stand Up NY</a>. That same year he was invited by the <a href="New%20York%20Friars%20Club">New York Friars Club</a> to participate in a roast of actor <a href="Steven%20Seagal">Steven Seagal</a>.
Ross became a regular at the Friars Club roasts and was given the title of "Roastmaster General". The Friars Club's first televised event was the roast of <a href="Drew%20Carey">Drew Carey</a> that was broadcast on <a href="Comedy%20Central">Comedy Central</a> in 1998. Ross credits a particular joke that he made at the expense of attendees <a href="Bea%20Arthur">Bea Arthur</a> and <a href="Sandra%20Bernhardt">Sandra Bernhardt</a> at the 1999 roast of <a href="Jerry%20Stiller">Jerry Stiller</a> for taking his roasting career to the next level. That same year <a href="Jimmy%20Kimmel">Jimmy Kimmel</a> hired Ross as a writer on "<a href="The%20Man%20Show">The Man Show</a>" and Ross also wrote some of the punchlines for <a href="Billy%20Crystal">Billy Crystal</a>'s monologue at the <a href="Academy%20Awards">Oscars</a> in 2000.
In 2003 Comedy Central began producing their own celebrity roasts. Ross has been a roaster at all Comedy Central roasts since the 2005 roast of <a href="Pamela%20Anderson">Pamela Anderson</a>. During his "Comedy Central Roast" appearances Ross became known for dressing-up in edgy and sometimes controversial costumes: He roasted <a href="Charlie%20Sheen">Charlie Sheen</a> dressed as <a href="Muammar%20Gaddafi">Muammar Gaddafi</a>; he roasted <a href="Rob%20Lowe">Rob Lowe</a> dressed as "<a href="Purple%20Rain%20%28film%29">Purple Rain</a>"-era <a href="Prince%20%28musician%29">Prince</a> on an episode that aired five months after the musician's death; he roasted <a href="Roseanne%20Barr">Roseanne Barr</a> dressed as the late football coach <a href="Joe%20Paterno">Joe Paterno</a> during the height of the <a href="Penn%20State%20child%20sex%20abuse%20scandal">Penn State child sex abuse scandal</a>; he also roasted <a href="James%20Franco">James Franco</a> wearing <a href="cornrows">cornrows</a> and a neck tattoo in reference to Franco's character in the 2012 film "<a href="Spring%20Breakers">Spring Breakers</a>".

Ross has taken part in several <a href="USO">USO</a> tours and has performed stand-up comedy at US Military bases in <a href="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>, <a href="Guantanamo%20Bay">Guantanamo Bay</a> and <a href="Iraq">Iraq</a>. Ross first traveled to Iraq in 2003 as part of a comedy tour hosted by <a href="Drew%20Carey">Drew Carey</a>. In 2005 Ross released the film "", which he both produced and directed and which documented his experiences on the Iraq tour. That same year the film won the prize for Best Film at the <a href="Comedia%20%28festival%29">Comedia film festival</a>, a comedy film festival held annually in <a href="Montreal">Montreal</a> as part of the <a href="Just%20for%20Laughs">Just for Laughs</a> comedy festival. In 2006 the film was shown on <a href="Showtime%20%28TV%20network%29">Showtime</a> and also screened at that year's <a href="South%20by%20Southwest%20Film%20Festival">South by Southwest Film Festival</a>. In 2017 the USO made Ross the Ambassador of Veterans Outreach for the Artists & Athletes Alliance.
Ross published his first book, "I Only Roast the Ones I Love: Busting Balls Without Burning Bridges", in 2009. The book recounts his journey to becoming Roastmaster General and includes tips on writing roast jokes and how to put on a roast.
Ross was the creator and host of the comedy <a href="panel%20show">panel show</a> "<a href="The%20Burn%20with%20Jeff%20Ross">The Burn with Jeff Ross</a>", which aired on Comedy Central for two seasons from 2012 to 2013.
In 2015, Ross starred in the Comedy Central special "Jeff Ross Roasts Criminals: Live from Brazos County Jail", where he performed stand-up comedy for male and female convicts in <a href="Brazos%20County%2C%20Texas">Brazos County, Texas</a>. The following year he released "Jeff Ross Roasts Cops" where he performed for members of the <a href="Boston%20Police%20Department">Boston Police Department</a>.
Ross and comedian Brian Moses launched "<a href="Jeff%20Ross%20Presents%20Roast%20Battle">Jeff Ross Presents Roast Battle</a>" on Comedy Central in 2016. The show consists of comedians competing in one-on-one roast battles where the winners are decided by Ross and a panel of guest judges. Ross also appeared as a battler in final episode of the show's third season in a battle with <a href="NBA">NBA</a> player <a href="Blake%20Griffin">Blake Griffin</a>.
In 2018 Ross and fellow comedian <a href="Dave%20Attell">Dave Attell</a> embarked on their "Bumping Mics" comedy tour. Footage of their tour was also released in a three-part special on <a href="Netflix">Netflix</a>. The "Bumping Mics" comedy special was filmed during three of their performances at the <a href="Comedy%20Cellar">Comedy Cellar</a> in New York City. Their shows consisted of <a href="observational%20humor">observational</a> and <a href="political%20humor">political humor</a> interspersed with Ross and Attell roasting one another as well as members of the audience. The comedians also invited audience members onto the stage, some of whom included <a href="Bob%20Saget">Bob Saget</a>, <a href="Gilbert%20Gottfried">Gilbert Gottfried</a>, <a href="Michael%20Che">Michael Che</a>, <a href="Amy%20Schumer">Amy Schumer</a>, <a href="Nikki%20Glaser">Nikki Glaser</a> and <a href="Paul%20Rudd">Paul Rudd</a>.
Starting in 2019, <a href="Netflix">Netflix</a> began airing the series "<a href="Historical%20Roasts">Historical Roasts</a>", where Ross hosts fictionalized versions of comedy roasts for figures like <a href="Abraham%20Lincoln">Abraham Lincoln</a> and <a href="Anne%20Frank">Anne Frank</a>.
Acting and voice work.
One of Ross's first acting roles was a small part in the 1996 comedy film "<a href="Celtic%20Pride">Celtic Pride</a>". Some of his other film roles include a security guard the film "<a href="Stuck%20on%20You%20%282003%20film%29">Stuck on You</a>" (2003) and a wedding band leader in the film "<a href="Along%20Came%20Polly">Along Came Polly</a>" (2004). Ross's television acting work includes roles on <a href="HBO">HBO</a>'s "<a href="Six%20Feet%20Under%20%28TV%20series%29">Six Feet Under</a>" and "<a href="Crashing%20%28U.S.%20TV%20series%29">Crashing</a>", and <a href="Showtime%20%28TV%20network%29">Showtime</a>'s "<a href="Weeds%20%28TV%20series%29">Weeds</a>". He also played a dramatic role on <a href="CBS">CBS</a>'s "".
Ross was co-creator of the <a href="satire">satirical</a> animated program "<a href="Where%20My%20Dogs%20At%3F">Where My Dogs At?</a>" that was broadcast on <a href="MTV2">MTV2</a> in 2006. The series centers around characters Buddy, a <a href="beagle">beagle</a> voiced by Ross, and Woof, a <a href="bulldog">bulldog</a> voiced by <a href="Tracy%20Morgan">Tracy Morgan</a>. Ross has also voiced a characters on two episodes of the animated series "<a href="Future-Worm%21">Future-Worm!</a>" as well as on an episode of the <a href="live-action%20animated%20film">live-action/animated</a> series "<a href="Happy%21%20%28TV%20series%29">Happy!</a>" An animated version of Jeff Ross (voiced by Ross himself) appears in an episode of "" that aired in 2012. During the episode his character attends a roast of <a href="Batman%20%28comics%29">Batman</a>.
Other appearances as himself.
Ross appeared in the 2005 documentary "<a href="The%20Aristocrats%20%28film%29">The Aristocrats</a>" about the famous <a href="The%20Aristocrats">dirty joke of the same name</a>.
He was the guest on the debut episode of the "<a href="WTF%20with%20Marc%20Maron">WTF with Marc Maron</a>" podcast in 2009 and also appeared on the podcast's 800th episode in 2017.
Ross appeared in the third tournament of <a href="Celebrity%20Poker">Celebrity Poker</a> in 2004, but lost in his first match. He was also a competitor on the <a href="Dancing%20with%20the%20Stars%20%28U.S.%20season%207%29">seventh season</a> of "<a href="Dancing%20with%20the%20Stars%20%28U.S.%20TV%20series%29">Dancing with the Stars</a>" that aired in 2008. During rehearsal for their first dance, his dancing partner <a href="Edyta%20%C5%9Aliwi%C5%84ska">Edyta Śliwińska</a> accidentally poked Ross in the eye, causing a scratched <a href="cornea">cornea</a>. Against medical advice, Ross continued the competition, but the couple were the first to be eliminated.
In 2011 Ross visited the protesters of the <a href="Occupy%20movement">Occupy movement</a> in Los Angeles to support their cause. He took to the microphone at a stage set-up at <a href="Los%20Angeles%20City%20Hall">Los Angeles City Hall</a>. His talk included roasting <a href="Wall%20Street">Wall Street</a> and the <a href="Big%20Four%20%28banking%29%23United%20States">big banks</a>.
In 2019, he appeared on an episode of "<a href="Crank%20Yankers">Crank Yankers</a>" as himself.
Sexual misconduct allegation.
In June 2020, an allegation that Ross had engaged in a sexual relationship with a 15-year-old when he was 34 was published in the media; his accuser, Jessica Radtke, had also posted these allegations on her <a href="Facebook">Facebook</a> page in 2019. In August, a "<a href="Vulture%20%28magazine%29">Vulture</a>" article stated that six unnamed people had confirmed that they were aware of the relationship. Radtke's father also said he approved of the relationship at the time. Ross denied the allegations. In November, Ross filed a defamation suit with the <a href="New%20York%20State%20Supreme%20Court">New York State Supreme Court</a>, in which multiple named witnesses (including Radtke's father) refuted her allegations; Radtke was accused of extorting Ross for "significant sums of money".
